headline: Exclusive: Taiwan to mark World War Two end in history narrative battle with China | Reuters
context: Item 1 of 3 Taiwan's President Lai Ching-te poses for a group photo at Songshan airbase in Taipei, Taiwan March 21, 2025. REUTERS/Ann Wang/File Photo
[1/3]Taiwan's President Lai Ching-te poses for a group photo at Songshan airbase in Taipei, Taiwan March 21, 2025. REUTERS/Ann Wang/File Photo Purchase Licensing Rights, opens new tab

annotations.paragraph: TAIPEI, May 2 (Reuters) - President Lai Ching-te will next week mark for the first time in Taiwan the end of World War Two in Europe and underscore that aggression must be defeated, sources told Reuters, at a time the island is facing increasing military pressure from China.
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces the main event and its significance in the context of Taiwan-China relations.

annotations.paragraph: Taiwan has since the start of this year sought to cast the war as a lesson to China in why aggression will end in failure, and take back the narrative from Beijing that it was not communist forces who took victory.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on Taiwan's narrative strategy regarding World War Two.

annotations.paragraph: The Reuters Tariff Watch newsletter is your daily guide to the latest global trade and tariff news. Sign up  here.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is an unrelated promotional content for a newsletter.

annotations.paragraph: World War Two, and the full-scale Japanese invasion of China in 1937 that preceded the start of the conflict in 1939, is a touchy historical subject in both China and Taiwan.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant historical context about the sensitivity of World War Two in China and Taiwan.

annotations.paragraph: The Chinese government at the time was the Republic of China, part of the U.S. and British-led alliance, and its forces did much of the fighting against Japan, putting on pause a bitter civil war with Mao Zedong's Communists whose military also fought the Japanese.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers historical context about China's role in World War Two, relevant to the narrative battle.

annotations.paragraph: The republican government then fled to Taiwan in 1949 after finally being defeated by Mao, and Republic of China remains the democratic island's official name.
annotations.reason: Provides historical context relevant to Taiwan's current political status.

annotations.paragraph: Four sources familiar with the matter, speaking on condition of anonymity as they were not authorised to speak to the media, told Reuters that Lai will host foreign diplomats and other dignitaries in Taipei on Thursday and give a speech about the 80th anniversary of the war's end.
annotations.reason: Introduces new information about an upcoming event related to the article's main topic.

annotations.paragraph: This marks the first time that Taiwan will formally commemorated the victory of the war in Europe. By doing so Lai is expected to call on the island's friends to unite in the face of the growing aggression from China, Russia, Iran and North Korea, two of the sources said.
annotations.reason: Provides details on the significance of the event and its geopolitical implications.

annotations.paragraph: "The victory in World War Two came from the unity of these nations, and it's important to note that aggression must be defeated. All these peace-loving nations must unite," the source said.
annotations.reason: Offers a direct quote that emphasizes the article's theme of unity against aggression.

annotations.paragraph: The source said Lai is likely to remind the world that democracies are now facing the same threats to democracy as 80 years ago, pointing to examples including China's military aggression, political coercion and disinformation campaigns.
annotations.reason: Highlights the relevance of historical events to current geopolitical challenges.

annotations.paragraph: Taiwan's presidential office did not respond to a request for comment.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a factual update on the lack of response from Taiwan's presidential office, relevant to the article's focus on Taiwan's actions.

annotations.paragraph: China's foreign ministry, asked about Taiwan's interpretation of the war and the events it is planning to mark its end, said the "distortion of history, tampering with facts and spreading of lies and fallacies" had long been a ploy of its ruling party.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides China's official stance on Taiwan's actions, directly relevant to the narrative battle mentioned in the headline.

annotations.paragraph: "Bringing about the reunification of the motherland and national rejuvenation are the best ways to commemorate the victory in the war," it said in a statement sent to Reuters.
annotations.reason: This paragraph contains a direct quote from China, providing insight into their perspective on the historical narrative, relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: Lai will be speaking ahead of the following day's military parade in Moscow hosted by President Vladimir Putin to mark the war's end, which Russia's government says Chinese President Xi Jinping will attend.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on the timing and significance of Lai's speech in relation to international events, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: Beijing claims democratically governed Taiwan as its own territory, a position the government in Taipei rejects.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides essential context on the political relationship between China and Taiwan, relevant to the article's main premise.

annotations.paragraph: The event will be held at the Taipei Guest House, the sources said, the residence of the governor general under Japanese colonial rule of Taiwan, which ended in 1945.
annotations.reason: Provides specific details about the location and historical significance of the event.

annotations.paragraph: A second source familiar with Lai's event next week said it was also about Taiwan trying to take back the narrative about the war from China.
annotations.reason: Directly relates to the main premise of the narrative battle with China.

annotations.paragraph: "Lai has a strong sense of history," the source said, pointing to previous comments from him including last year where he said if China's claims on Taiwan are about territorial integrity then it should also take back land from Russia signed over by the last Chinese dynasty in the 19th century.
annotations.reason: Provides context on Lai's historical perspective and stance on territorial claims.

annotations.paragraph: Lai, who took office in May last year, is condemned by Beijing as a "separatist". He says only Taiwan's people can decide their future.
annotations.reason: Offers relevant information on Lai's political stance and Beijing's view of him.

annotations.paragraph: Reporting by Ben Blanchard and Yimou Lee; Additional reporting by Joe Cash in Beijing; Editing by Lincoln Feast.
annotations.reason: Standard reporting credits, not contributing to the narrative.

annotations.paragraph: Our Standards: The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles., opens new tab
annotations.reason: This paragraph is a standard disclaimer about Reuters' principles and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: Ben joined Reuters as a company news reporter in Shanghai in 2003 before moving to Beijing in 2005 to cover Chinese politics and diplomacy. In 2019 Ben was appointed the Taiwan bureau chief covering everything from elections and entertainment to semiconductors.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides background information about a reporter and does not contribute directly to the article's main premise.

annotations.paragraph: Yimou Lee is a Senior Correspondent for Reuters covering everything from Taiwan, including sensitive Taiwan-China relations, China's military aggression and Taiwan's key role as a global semiconductor powerhouse. A three-time SOPA award winner, his reporting from Hong Kong, China, Myanmar and Taiwan over the past decade includes Myanmar's crackdown on Rohingya Muslims, Hong Kong protests and Taiwan's battle against China's multifront campaigns to absorb the island.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides background information about a correspondent and does not contribute directly to the article's main premise.
